commit_message:
Massively Distributed RPC test plan

This formalizes the discussion started in
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/1BGhFHDIoi

Change-Id: Idc7ab4eeef24ef57a535b9567541f30734191e87
Co-Authored-By: Ken Giusti <kgiusti@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: andy smith <ansmith@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Paul-Andre Raymond <paul-andre.raymond@b-yond.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/performance-docs refs/changes/18/491818/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _message_queue_performance: ========================== Massively Distributed RPCs ========================== :status: **draft** :version: 1.0 :Abstract: This document describes a test plan for evaluating the OpenStack message bus in the context of a massively distributed cloud architecture. For instance, a massively distributed cloud addresses, the use case of the Fog or Edge computing where the services are geographically distributed accross a large area. For the time being, OpenStack inter-service communications rely on oslo_messaging which defines a common abstraction to different instanciations of a message bus (e.g RabbitMQ, AMQP, Zero-MQ). The test plan takes place in the context of a prospective effort to evaluate the distribution of the messaging bus using emerging solutions (e.g qpid dispatch router) or established one (e.g Zero-MQ) compared to the traditionnal and centralized solutions (e.g RabbitMQ). The scope of the test plan is RPC communication between OpenStack services, thus notification is out of the scope of this effort. Test Plan ========= This section describes the setup for the communication bus testing. This can be splitted in two parts : 1. synthetic testing 2. operationnal testing The former is performed on top of oslo_messaging in isolation from any OpenStack components whereas the latter intends to evaluate the correct behaviour and the performance of OpenStack using similar deployment of the messaging middleware. Synthetic testing ================= Test Dimensions --------------- The dimensions are identified parameters that can influence the overall performance of the messaging middleware. - Message payload size This can be a fixed value. In case of dynamic values, the distribution of the values from which they are taken must be indicated. - Message generation rate (messages/sec) This can be a fixed value. In case of dynamic values, the distribution of the values from which they are taken must be indicated. - RPC Server capacity Number of servers per topic - RPC Client load: Number of clients per RPC Server - Messaging middleware topology The actual deployment of the messaging middleware. A graph may be used to illustrate thoroughly the topology of the messaging entities. e.g : federated RabbitMQ clusters, set of qdrouterd daemons .. include:: environment_description.rst Tools ----- - `ombt2`_ - oslo messaging `simulator`_ Test Case 1 : RPC Call performance metrics ------------------------------------------ Methodology ^^^^^^^^^^^^ .. code-block:: none Start: * Provision a single RPC server on the default topic * Provision a single RPC client * RPC client issues calls to topic: - full rate Repeat: * Add additional clients until RPC server CPU utilization reaches >70% * Provision another RPC server (default topic) Metrics ^^^^^^^ The following metrics are recorded for each repetition ======== ========== ================= ================================= Priority Value Measurement Units Description ======== ========== ================= ================================= 1 Throughput msg/sec Number of messages per second 2 Variance msg/sec Throughput variance over time 2 Latency ms The latency in message processing ======== ========== ================= ================================= .. note:: The latency can correspond to different time : - client-side latency, the time taken in the execution flow of the sender to make the RPC. - end to end latency, time taken for a RPC to reach all the servers involved in the request. Test Case 2 : RPC Cast performance metrics ------------------------------------------ Same as above with RPC cast instead of RCP call ======== ========== ================= ================================= Priority Value Measurement Units Description ======== ========== ================= ================================= 1 Throughput msg/sec Number of messages per second 2 Variance msg/sec Throughput variance over time 2 Latency ms The latency in message processing ======== ========== ================= ================================= Test Case 3 : RPC fanout perfomance metrics ------------------------------------------- Methodology ^^^^^^^^^^^ .. code-block:: none Start: * Provision a single RPC server on the default topic * Provision a single RPC client * RPC client issues fanout cast to topic: - 1 cast every second - n messages Repeat: * Add additional RPC server on the default topic Metrics ^^^^^^^ In case of fanout cast, no ack are sent to the sender. The latency will be the time interval between the message is sent and the message is received by all the servers. Test Case 4 : Resilience ------------------------ Usual centralized solutions offer some solution to increase their scalability while providing high-availibility (e.g RabbitMQ clustering, mirroring). This kind of solution fit well the one-datacenter case but doesn't cope with the distributed case where high latency between communicating entities can be observed. In a massively distributed case, communicating entities may fail more often (link down, hardware failure). The goal of this test case is to evaluate the resiliency of the messaging layer to failures. This test case fit well the case where the messaging layer is composed of a set of messaging agents (e.g qdrouterd) where alternatives routes can be found upon failure. Methodology ^^^^^^^^^^^ TODO Metrics ^^^^^^^ TODO Common metrics to all test cases -------------------------------- For each agent involved in the communication middleware, metrics about their resource consumption under load must be gathered. ======== ================= ================= ================================= Priority Value Measurement Units Description ======== ================= ================= ================================= 1 CPU load Mhz CPU load 2 RAM consumption Gb RAM consumption 3 Opened Connection Number of TCP sockets opened ======== ================= ================= ================================= Operationnal testing ==================== Operational testing intends to evaluate the correct behaviour of a running OpenStack on top of a specific deployment of the messaging middleware. Test Dimensions --------------- - Messaging middleware topology Compared to the test dimensions of the synthetic testing part, the deployment of the messaging middleware is kept. The other parameters will be enforced by the running OpenStack installation. - Openstack service topology and specific configuration e.g: cell / no cell deployment, Neutron deployment. .. include:: environment_description.rst Tools ----- - `EnOS`_ - `Rally`_ Test Case 1 : Rally benchmarks ------------------------------ This test case aims to measure the correct behaviour of OpenStack under WAN at messaging plane level. It relies on `Rally`_ that runs loads on the current OpenStack. Then Rally reports can be used to get time of operations executions and percent of failure to evaluate OpenStack. The chosen Rally scenarios and those known to be intensive on the messaging layer. Rally scenario to consider : * `Neutron scenarios`_ : all * `Nova scenarios`_ : - ``boot-and-associate-floating-ip`` - ``boot-and-delete`` - ``boot-server-and-attach-interface`` - ``boot-and-list`` .. references: .. _ombt2: https://github.com/kgiusti/ombt .. _simulator: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/tools/simulator.py .. _EnOS: https://github.com/BeyondTheClouds/enos .. _Rally: https://github.com/openstack/rally .. _Neutron scenarios: https://github.com/openstack/rally/tree/0aa2f58e43ff143a27880b5fa527b09c7670d5f7/samples/tasks/scenarios/neutron .. _Nova scenarios: https://github.com/openstack/rally/tree/0aa2f58e43ff143a27880b5fa527b09c7670d5f7/samples/tasks/scenarios/nova Reports =======

A backend may advertise "thin_provisioning_support" to the
Cinder scheduler, but may not have an efficient way to calculate

commit_message:
Fix provisioned_capacity_gb for drivers that don't report it

A backend may advertise "thin_provisioning_support" to the
Cinder scheduler, but may not have an efficient way to calculate
the "provisioned_capacity_gb" on that backend. The assumption
in Cinder has been that we will fall back on the
allocated_capacity_gb for such backends.

Change-Id: I72175890d67804b19883c1e6503833dd10806cf5
Related-Bug: #1714209
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/78/523478/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (pool.get('thin_provisioning_support') and 'provisioned_capacity_gb' not in pool): pool['provisioned_capacity_gb'] = ( pool['allocated_capacity_gb'] )

commit_message:
Download Kubespray instead of git clone

We don't install git by default (at least in CI), so let's use a
tarball instead of git clone to get Kubespray sources.

Change-Id: I8321206b095effbc482779a10ff77fd18299bbdf
Depends-On: I2da025961c584cb1adc83943561b1d9faa3559b1

added_lines: - name: download kubespray source shell: | set -eux mkdir '{{ kubespray_dir }}' cd '{{ kubespray_dir }}' curl -Lo kubespray.tar.gz 'https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/kubespray/archive/master.tar.gz' tar --strip-components 1 -xzvf kubespray.tar.gz # do not overwrite existing contents when: not kubespray_stat.stat.exists and not kubespray_cloned_stat.stat.exists
deleted_lines: - name: clone kubespray repo git: repo: https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/kubespray dest: "{{ kubespray_dir }}" update: no when: not kubespray_stat.stat.exists

commit_message:
Fix admin/project instance UT

The expected error count was wrongly changed in
commit df194c8b4c25c6128f03a98fd0e628ba14b743ff.

The expected error count was changed from 1 to 2 in the commit
but one new error message was caused by a wrong test code.
api.glance.image_list_detailed should return a tuple of
(images, has_more, has_prev) but the mocked method only returns
a list of images and this causes another error.

Change-Id: Ic1083014f9572bfd20adc60e7ec3eeeac387e9d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/52/522652/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .AndReturn((images, False, False))

subject: Use oslo.config for Horizon configuration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-30 11:54:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/7a1537250238adf1e39ab17fb689d8b47c426ce4', 'message': "Move all Django configuration into .conf file

All Django-related configuration options have been moved into
the local_settings.conf file. All the post-processing logic is
still there in settings.py.

Note, that those options will still work if specified in
local_settings.py or local_settings.d -- I'm basically adding
one more source of configuration. We can remove the original
config files once we migrate everything.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bp/ini-based-settings
Change-Id: I2ed79ef0c6ac6d3816bba13346b7d001c46a7e80

commit_message:
Use oslo.config for Horizon configuration

This patch adds the infrastructure needed to move the configuration
of Horizon into oslo.config-compatible configuration file, instead of
the Django's Python-based configuration. It doesn't actually define
any configuration options, just the mechanism for loading them and the
additional types necessary to handle Horizon's complex configuration,
and the integration with oslo-config-generator.

Subsequent patches will add groups of options, making it possible to use
them in the local_settings.conf file instead of the local_settings.py
file. Note, that the options specified in the local_settings.py file
will continue to work.

Partially-Implements: blueprint ini-based-configuration
Change-Id: I2ed79ef0c6ac6d3816bba13346b7d001c46a7e80
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/35/404735/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import globfrom openstack_dashboard.utils import configSECRET_KEY = None LOCAL_PATH = None# allow to drop settings snippets into a local_settings_dir if not LOCAL_PATH: LOCAL_PATH = os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, 'local') LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH = os.path.join(LOCAL_PATH, "local_settings.d") if os.path.exists(LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH): for (dirpath, dirnames, filenames) in os.walk(LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH): for filename in sorted(filenames): if filename.endswith(".py"): try: with open(os.path.join(dirpath, filename)) as f: exec(f.read()) except Exception as e: logging.exception( "Can not exec settings snippet %s" % filename) _files = [] _files.extend(glob.glob(os.path.join(LOCAL_PATH, 'local_settings.conf'))) _files.extend(sorted(glob.glob(os.path.join(LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH, '*.conf')))) _config = config.load_config(_files, ROOT_PATH, LOCAL_PATH) # Apply the general configuration. config.apply_config(_config, __name__) # configure templates if not TEMPLATES[0]['DIRS']: TEMPLATES[0]['DIRS'] = os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, 'templates') DEFAULT_THEME,

subject: tripleo-buildimage: deploy repo in pre-run
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-27 17:04:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/2fa93248c2bbfda74ae5b23fd47c43862346c5cb', 'message': 'tripleo-buildimage: deploy repo in pre-run

OpenStack Infra removed the centos-release-openstack-ocata rpm from
nodepool-centos7 image, so tripleo build images job started to fail
because we need qemu-img-ev in bindep (provided by RDO repo).

commit_message:
tripleo-buildimage: deploy repo in pre-run

OpenStack Infra removed the centos-release-openstack-ocata rpm from
nodepool-centos7 image, so tripleo build images job started to fail
because we need qemu-img-ev in bindep (provided by RDO repo).

So this patch brings back the package prior to run the actual tests.

Change-Id: Ie760e2b61dd76cb680dd2f4e553d3fb6c9b889aa

'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2017-08-09 14:49:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/1dcad17120fa1de0959fdad456c596462761287f', 'message': 'WIP Trunks panel: edit button

TODO tests

Trunk edit is a 2-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector step reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I4a9f3bd710c9f6bc9ed942b107c6720865b1bc73
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

commit_message:
Trunks panel: edit button

Trunk edit is a 2-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector step reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I4a9f3bd710c9f6bc9ed942b107c6720865b1bc73
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

You may obtain * a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT * WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations * under the License. */ (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.app.core.trunks') .factory('horizon.app.core.trunks.actions.editWorkflow', editWorkflow); editWorkflow.$inject = [ 'horizon.app.core.trunks.basePath', 'horizon.app.core.workflow.factory', 'horizon.framework.util.i18n.gettext' ]; /** * @ngdoc factory * @name horizon.app.core.trunks.editWorkflow * @description A workflow for the edit trunk action. */ function editWorkflow( basePath, workflowService, gettext) { var workflow = workflowService({ title: gettext('Edit Trunk'), btnText: { finish: gettext('Edit Trunk') }, steps: [ { title: gettext('Details'), templateUrl: basePath + 'steps/trunk-details.html', helpUrl: basePath + 'steps/trunk-details.help.html', formName: 'detailsForm' }, { title: gettext('Subports'), templateUrl: basePath + 'steps/trunk-subports.html', helpUrl: basePath + 'steps/trunk-subports.help.html', formName: 'subportsForm' } ] }); return workflow; } })();

'}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2017-07-18 13:18:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4d8f9378be1491df1d5c69cf251c83bc7b82a68d', 'message': "Trunks panel: create button

Reused and built on port allocator transfertable from launch instance.

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

To test it devstack needs to have neutron with trunk support, eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

No special horizon config is needed. As long as the 'trunk'
API extension is available (openstack extension show trunk)
the panel should automatically appear under Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

TODO unit tests: better coverage

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

No special horizon config is needed. As long as the 'trunk'
API extension is available (openstack extension show trunk)
the panel should automatically appear under Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

"}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2017-08-09 14:49:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/495e83524437688b5e031c0dde71a36e12acd35e', 'message': "WIP Trunks panel: create button

TODO #1 tackle the deprecated use of initScope in actions
        cf. https://review.openstack.org/345145
TODO #2 get rid of the inconsistencies of crossHide
        maybe solving #1 first will help
TODO #3 adapt tests to changes in the last few patch sets

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

TODO adapt tests to changes in the last few patch sets

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:

  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

commit_message:
Trunks panel: create button

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/96/468396/41 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def trunk_create(request, **params): LOG.debug("trunk_create(): params=%s", params) if 'project_id' not in params: params['project_id'] = request.user.project_id body = {'trunk': params} trunk = neutronclient(request).create_trunk(body=body).get('trunk') return Trunk(trunk) @profiler.trace

commit_message:
Remove agent/dhcp_agent_scheduler extensions

networking-ovn doesn't actually support these extensions, so
remove them.

Change-Id: Ic9ef37a80116bb0166d3638ad2789a995480e7db
(cherry picked from commit 8f0942cbed9e55f071d297d34dfbc8784b448ba5)

commit_message:
Only monitor the necessary SB tables for changes

There is no reason to waste memory storing tables in the
Southbound DB that we don't use.

Change-Id: Iba03bbd735f61c16dcc22b5d11d030bd18549b5b
(cherry picked from commit 0e34fbab5edb9999c48b44c3efa8b08b61216127)

commit_message:
[placement] Fix GET PUT /allocations nits

In the review of I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc, a few
non-blocking nits were identified. This change addresses some of
those nits, fixing some typos, clarifying method names and what
microversion is in use at particular times.

Change-Id: Iff15340502ce43eba3b98db26aa0652b1da24504

DNS queries failures.

commit_message:
Switch to lib/neutron

Plan is to move to devstack/lib/neutron, but networking-odl uses
devstack/lib/neutron-legacy. This patch switch networking-odl from
lib/neutron-legacy to lib/neutron. There are some changes in the
lib/neutron, now services names are going to be neutron-api,
neutron-dhcp, neutron-metadata-agent etc instead of q-svc, q-dhcp
and q-meta.

Change-Id: Id9365d022eef030685eea752b5dabff655931bdb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/97/504297/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if is_neutron_legacy_enabled; then devstack_localrc $w disable_service neutron-agent devstack_localrc $w disable_service neutron-l3 devstack_localrc $w enable_service neutron-dhcp devstack_localrc $w enable_service neutron-metadata else devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-agt devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-l3 devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-dhcp devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-meta fi
deleted_lines: devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-agt devstack_localrc $w disable_service q-l3 devstack_localrc $w enable_service q-dhcp devstack_localrc $w enable_service q-meta

commit_message:
Outline policy goals

This document is intended to document the goals we need from a policy
implementation. In addition to that, this document also suggests some
cross-project tools we can use to help make progress towards better
policy in OpenStack.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Young <ayoung@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt <john@johngarbutt.com>

Change-Id: I57b2b38db8d5d9368a1056363a87788572712338
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/44/460344/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============ Policy Goals ============ Policy in OpenStack has long been the forefront of operator concerns and pain. The implementation is complicated to understand, distributed, and lacks security centric defaults. The purpose of this document is to identify the use cases OpenStack needs in a policy implementation and to level-set on various policy terminology and context. Use Cases ========= The following list would increase OpenStack adopting by solving immediate security issues within OpenStack, providing documentation and default roles to operators, and enabling better delegation workflows by allowing operation-role review: 1. As an operator, I should be able to grant an `admin` role to a user on a project without compromising data outside of the project. 2. As an operator, I should be able to easily understand which policy maps to a particular operation or API. 3. As an operation, I should have a variety of sensible roles at my disposal upon installation that I can assign to users. 4. As an operator, I should be able to easily modify and maintain my own policies. 5. As a user, I should be able to determine what I can do in a given deployment. 6. As a user, I should be able to review the roles I have and which policies they allow me to use. Future Use Cases ================ The following use cases have been brought up in discussions several times. At this point we are not ruling out the possibility of addressing these use cases, but formally recognizing them as something to be addressed after delivering the use cases in the previous section (i.e. you must crawl before you can walk, and walk before you can run). 1. As a user, I should be able to give fine-grained access to another user or system. 2. As an operator, I should be able to build custom policies that can take into account users, resources, and scopes. Cross-Project Impact ==================== Policy and Role Based Access Control (RBAC) has traditionally been thought of as problem space within the OpenStack Identity umbrella. While that statement is true, the current implementation of policy across the OpenStack services makes the ownership of the problem harder to pin point. The keystone team has made several attempts to address these issues (linked below in the References section), but having the implementation spread across OpenStack makes it impossible for a single project to propose and fix these issues without cross-project buy-in. One tool that at our disposal today is the usage of `Community Goals <https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/>`_ to help move projects in an agreed-upon direction. The process would fit nicely with this specific problem because it would require cross-project communication, buy-in, and commitment. Ideally, if the work proposed to address the above use cases requires cross-project coordination, we should propose the agreed upon approach as a cross-project community goal. An alternative to using cross-project goals would be to define one, or multiple, use cases into sensible `tags <https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/index.html>`_ that projects can achieve. For example, if a project develops and tests a specific set of roles and implements them, they can `assert:basic-rbac`. References ========== `Role Check from Middleware specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/391624>`_ `Tokens with subsets of roles specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/186979>`_ `Role Check on Body Key specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456974>`_ `Dynamic RBAC Policy specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279379>`_ `Policy Merge specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/295049>`_ `Fetch Policy by Tag specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/298788>`_ `Policy rules managed from a database specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/133814>`_ `Add policy-remove-scope-checks specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433037/>`_ `Add additional-default-policy-roles specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/427872/>`_ `Add policy-docs specification <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/433010/>`_

commit_message:
Remove httpd log dir for glance-api

Glance API still runs eventlet, the
/var/log/containers/httpd/glance-api directory on the host serves no
purpose and confuses users. Remove it.

Change-Id: Idcd26571d20f02b723af9938ba625c9fa548c0d7
Closes-Bug: #1728562

commit_message:
Release python-brick-cinderclient-ext 0.6.0

The currently python-brick-cinderclient-ext does not
work with the latest release of os-brick (2.1.0).
This release includes a fix to remove deprecated
constants and move to using the appropriate
constants.

There is an update to dependencies included so doing
this a feature release bumping 0.5.0 to 0.6.0.

Change-Id: Ibbc803fc053d030ab88e95d578ce07125c191972

commit_message:
Remove zone_id on import compare

If the import is fast, it can be done by the show, so we can't compare
zone_id.

Closes-Bug: #1734868

commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

Also, use openstackdocstheme for releasenotes.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I1357eda2330c095bdc1e3a3697faabfbca4b6a8e

commit_message:
Remove a redundant self argument in decorators

The wrapper function takes *func_args and **kwargs,
therefore, "self" argument is redundant.

Change-Id: Ibbe7acfe4cb91d4f1b26d96dbc5088a4720a2b56

commit_message:
Fix for timeouts on scale down

There were two issues: The action timeout and the wait_for_messages
timeout.

The wait_for_messages did not need a timeout here and it was causing the
bug. I added an cli option for the timeout and setup a reasonable
default (the previous default was over 4 hours that would invalidate
keystone session duration)

Change-Id: I232d071516d3f53f9f87143d9d65ebe3e58b0f38
Closes-Bug: 1734712
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/63/522863/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parser.add_argument( '--timeout', metavar='<TIMEOUT>', type=int, default=constants.TIMEOUT, dest='timeout', help=_("Timeout in minutes to wait for the nodes to be deleted. " "Keep in mind that due to keystone session duration " "that timeout has an upper bound of 4 hours ") ) scale.scale_down( clients, stack.stack_name, parsed_args.nodes, parsed_args.timeout )

commit_message:
Add exclude list to not override user data

Add an exclude list of file which can possibly
contains user data.
When those files are modified by the user, we should
not erased those when we update the plan during the
upgrade

Change-Id: I4e53d8f95170c25b32a6d714a7620c2c9d2596f3
Closes-Bug: #1734108

commit_message:
link to the mitaka CLI guide

Replace the use of the project_guides.tmpl template in the mitaka
index file with inline versions that link to the mitaka-specific
pages.

Add a language-bindings.html page based on the one for ocata to link
to the user-guide and cli-reference for mitaka.

Add a projects.html page to link to the mitaka documentation for each
service project.

Change-Id: I173ecabeb3aa74a3d2ddc6b4ba898d881dcf752d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
link to mitaka versions of admin and user guides

As part of the documentation retention policy change, we recovered the
user, admin, and CLI guides for Mitaka. This patch links to the first
two. Linking to the CLI guide will come later in this patch series.

Change-Id: I3b6981ad01fb00944f65cdd13682c9ca531393c2
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: remove extraneous retry assignment in cleanup method

The retry = False assignments in these blocks was pointless
because we raise an exception out of them anyway, so the retry
variable isn't going to be read again.

Change-Id: Ie52044ed9ad8520e3878de60365cdea22596aa78

commit_message:
Don't create new QoS policy during update operation

The QoS plugin erroneously creates a new policy when updating
an existing one.
This causes the loss of previously set attributes that are
not passed in the update call.

This patch fixes this issue by getting existing qos policy object
instead of creating a new one for update.

This issue is already fixed in Pike branch with patch:
I57011bd4d40479855203061554090d19bb668960

Change-Id: I6f5a925084bb70b56e66d673eac2febdb38e0b34
Related-Bug: #1734136
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/33/523133/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(policy_object.QosPolicy, "get_object") mock_qos_policy_get = mocks[1] mock_qos_policy_get.return_value = self.policy # NOTE(slaweq): in case of update existing qos_policy_object # is taken with get_object() method so mocked call is different if action == "update": policy_mock_call = getattr( mock.call.QosPolicy.get_object(), action)() else: policy_mock_call = getattr(mock.call.QosPolicy(), action)()

commit_message:
cluster-create support volume_type

Now we just parse the volume_type parameter in cluster/service.py,
but it is not passed in the creat instance, which will be
supported here.

Change-Id: Iae790e54ebf1bd6cb968c3be4c3f5cd53e1082f7
Partial-Bug: #1622957

commit_message:
Move default policies into code

This is part of a community effort to provide better user experience
for those having to maintain RBAC policy. More information on this
effort can be found below:

  https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/policy-in-code.html

bp policy-and-docs-in-code
Co-authored-By: Hieu LE <hieulq@vn.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: I9bad70abcf5543c3e5e5da25c56c408ee3ff0346

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Add package install assertions to SUSE base image""

Changes have been made to this revert to ensure we're installing the
needed packages to use the new version of systemd. This change also adds
more testing so we're doing everything we can combat regressions.

This reverts commit 6464003460f9bdc9f83876f0b133196b92cd8926.

Change-Id: I103a430b6bf7c63e817637f8604a8e0bb5ce22d8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
periodic py jobs for vmware-nsx ocata and pike

The vmware-nsx project would like to implement periodic jobs to verify
py27/py35 tests on stable branches (stable/pike, stable/ocata). This
patch adds the periodic job definitions to the vmware-nsx project
pipeline.

Change-Id: I6c88f895e4af4ea255df169ba060b28381a052d4

commit_message:
Check that network interface exsits before adjusting MTU

If the network interface does not exist or is removed,
adjusting the MTU will fail.

Change-Id: Ie4c7ba1929c78f7c433bf1827128a55f2a1386a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/19/504419/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ ! -z "$(cat /proc/net/dev | grep {{ interface }})" ]]; then ip link set {{ interface }} mtu {{ mtu }} echo "MTU={{ mtu }}" >> /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-{{ interface }} fi
deleted_lines: ip link set {{ interface }} mtu {{ mtu }} echo "MTU={{ mtu }}" >> /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-{{ interface }}

subject: [placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-01 14:30:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9eff3e01b0c2550c6279c7cec3ab555bc33dbb6a', 'message': "WIP: [placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

Throwing this up for early feedback and because I may not be able
to give it attention for a little while, so wanted to make sure
it was visible.

This gives a proof of concept implementation of POSTing to
/allocations to set allocations for multiple consumers, such as an
an instance and a migration uuid. Conceptually it is relatively
simple: build an AllocationList of Allocation objects and
create_al(). But there are some wrinkles:

* The association between consumer_uuid and project id is only done
  for the consumer of the first allocation, resulting in bad /usages
  data when querying by project or user

* There's no jsonschema yet. I couldn't figure out how to write one
  without a reference and was without net

* This uses a dict-based representation of allocations, based on the
  response to GET. We may wish to use a list based style, which is
  what is currently used on PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}, but
  see https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1708204 and comments on
  the spec review about some preference for dict

* If we fix the issue with project consumer association in
  straightforward way it ought to allow allocations from multiple
  project/user

* There are many TODOs (especially related to duplication) and
  FIXMEs scattered throughout

Change-Id: I239f33841bb9fcd92b406f979674ae8c5f8d57e3
Implements: bp post-allocations
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-09-04 00:31:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b9b79b5a3be69d6c887e26ab39aeb0ab82135810', 'message': "WIP: [placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

Throwing this up for early feedback and because I may not be able
to give it attention for a little while, so wanted to make sure
it was visible.

This gives a proof of concept implementation of POSTing to
/allocations to set allocations for multiple consumers, such as an
an instance and a migration uuid. Conceptually it is relatively
simple: build an AllocationList of Allocation objects and
create_al(). But there are some wrinkles:

* There's no jsonschema yet. I couldn't figure out how to write one
  without a reference and was without net

* This uses a dict-based representation of allocations, based on the
  response to GET. We may wish to use a list based style, which is
  what is currently used on PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}, but
  see https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1708204 and comments on
  the spec review about some preference for dict

Change-Id: I239f33841bb9fcd92b406f979674ae8c5f8d57e3
Implements: bp post-allocations
"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2017-09-13 22:10:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c35d2a571db790cb5ee465e5a9d13a458f40a31d', 'message': "WIP: [placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

"}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2017-10-10 12:21:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0209eb7b3d6446450193766ca8eefbe7a94c0b67', 'message': "[placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

This provides microversions 1.12 of the placement API, giving the
ability to POST to /allocations to set (or clear) allocations for
more than one consumer uuid.

This builds on the recent work to support a dict-based JSON format
when doing a PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}.

Being able to set allocations for multiple consumers in one request
helps to address race conditions when cleaning up allocations during
move operations in nova.

Clearing allocations is done by setting the 'allocations' key to an
empty dict.

Docs and reno in a subsequent patch, after we determine if this is
actually what we want.

Change-Id: I239f33841bb9fcd92b406f979674ae8c5f8d57e3
Implements: bp post-allocations
"}, {'number': 20, 'created': '2017-10-10 13:40:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/609ad379af66087ccc732578f8dc7de6d1864ffd', 'message': "[placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

more than one consumer uuid.

when doing a PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}.

helps to address race conditions when cleaning up allocations during
move operations in nova.

Clearing allocations is done by setting the 'allocations' key for a
specific consumer to an empty dict.

Updates to placement-api-ref, rest version history and a reno are
included.

Change-Id: I239f33841bb9fcd92b406f979674ae8c5f8d57e3
Implements: bp post-allocations
"}]
commit_message:
[placement] POST /allocations to set allocations for >1 consumers

This provides microversion 1.13 of the placement API, giving the
ability to POST to /allocations to set (or clear) allocations for
more than one consumer uuid.

It builds on the recent work to support a dict-based JSON format
when doing a PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}.

Being able to set allocations for multiple consumers in one request
helps to address race conditions when cleaning up allocations during
move operations in nova.

Clearing allocations is done by setting the 'allocations' key for a
specific consumer to an empty dict.

Updates to placement-api-ref, rest version history and a reno are
included.

Change-Id: I239f33841bb9fcd92b406f979674ae8c5f8d57e3
Implements: bp post-allocations

commit_message:
Always generate ARA subunit results

We'd like to see our tests results show up in OpenStack Health
regardless of whether the test passed or failed. This patch
makes sure that it will always try to generate them.

It also implements a routine to try and find where ARA is
installed, because it's not always in a tox venv called
'functional' which was the previously hard-coded location.

Change-Id: I3d967567af9d9c9583f34c89789a38e60717781e
(cherry picked from commit 2fb00b67edb249d47a422434757f406926b747a0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests refs/changes/29/523329/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/ara" \${RSYNC_CMD} "${TESTING_HOME}/.ara/ansible.sqlite" "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/ara/" || true # Figure out the correct path for ARA # As this script is not run through tox, and the tox envs are all # different names, we need to try and find the right path to execute # ARA from. ARA_CMD="$(find ${WORKING_DIR}/.tox -path "*/bin/ara" -type f | head -n 1)" # If we could not find ARA, assume it was not installed # and skip all the related activities. if [[ "${ARA_CMD}" != "" ]]; then # Generate the ARA report # In order to reduce the quantity of unnecessary log content # being kept in OpenStack-Infra we only generate the ARA report # when the test result is a failure. The ARA sqlite database is # still available for self generation if desired for successful # tests. if [[ "${TEST_EXIT_CODE}" != "0" ]] && [[ "${TEST_EXIT_CODE}" != "true" ]]; then echo "Generating ARA report." ${ARA_CMD} generate html "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/ara" || true else echo "Not generating ARA report." fi # We still want the subunit report though, as that reflects # success/failure in OpenStack Health ${ARA_CMD} generate subunit "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/ara/testrepository.subunit" || true
deleted_lines: export ARA_CMD="${WORKING_DIR}/.tox/functional/bin/ara generate html"${RSYNC_CMD} "${TESTING_HOME}/.ara/ansible.sqlite" "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/" || true # Generate the ARA report # In order to reduce the quantity of unnecessary log content # being kept in OpenStack-Infra we only generate the ARA report # when the test result is a failure. The ARA sqlite database is # still available for self generation if desired for successful # tests. if [[ "${TEST_EXIT_CODE}" != "0" ]] && [[ "${TEST_EXIT_CODE}" != "true" ]]; then echo "Generating ARA report." ${ARA_CMD} "${WORKING_DIR}/logs/ara" || true else echo "Not generating ARA report."

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated TrustedFilter and related options

The TrustedFilter and the related trusted_computing config
options were deprecated in Pike:

  If6e53feeb97e6050c1eb7962110ed89504c952fc

This change removes them along with related documentation.

Change-Id: I26ce2de6435a9956d1c28e04221fa4a8d140833c

commit_message:
Regenerate and pass configdrive when rebuild Ironic nodes

Previously, the configdrive could only be set when setting
the node's provisioning state to "active". When rebuilding,
the old configdrive was used and therefore was never updated
with latest content.

Since Ironic API microversion 1.35, it is now allowed to provide
a configdrive when setting the node's provisioning state to "rebuild".

Blueprint: rebuild-ironic-config-drive
Related-bug: #1575935
Depends-On: I9a5529f9fa796c75621e9f4354886bf3032cc248
Change-Id: I1f9056f66519b9ca2f4e23143559735f2bff8943

Because people may use these more familiar "file system" names in

Change-Id: I30524f80a341f38dfa794a8f629d859e85a4a448

commit_message:
Convert to safe name in lib_installed_from_git

The 'pip list' command prints the "safe name" which converts _'s to
-'s amongst other things; e.g. glance_store becomes

  "glance-store             0.21.1.dev22      /opt/stack/glance_store"

Because people may use these more familiar "file system" names in
LIBS_FROM_GIT automatically convert names when checking if libraries
are installed.

Change-Id: I30524f80a341f38dfa794a8f629d859e85a4a448

commit_message:
[placement] Clean up TODOs in allocations.yaml gabbit

With the avent of gabbi 1.35.0 (already in test-requirements),
subtitutions in the left hand side of a json path check are now allowed.
allocations.yaml had two TODOs related to this which this change fixes.

Also fixed:

* a TODO about the nature of consumer id's is changed to a NOTE since
  the behavior is as designed
* a whitespace nit is fixed, since I'm in here already may as well

Change-Id: I3bbeb2bcf0ae23467f795dc6fb4a1de46c08d3ef

In the # meantime we have to jump over it. This works because we only # have one resource provider in this output. $.allocations..generation: 7 $.allocations..resources.DISK_GB: 20 $.allocations..resources.VCPU: 4 # TODO(cdent): Can't currently do substitution on the left hand # side of json path in gabbi, a bug has been made. In the # meantime we have to jump over the resource provider (which # we don't know as a static value). This works because we only # have one resource provider in this output. $.allocations..generation: 7 $.allocations..DISK_GB: 10

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-28 13:38:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/6e9aea78a5d186de8518a1558e960f8aec2fc6f7', 'message': "Fix role schema in trust object

trust except to validate that it was an array. A hasty glance, however,
would lead you to believe that it was validating an array of

commit_message:
Fix role schema in trust object

Previously, we weren't doing any validation on the roles attribute of a
trust except to validate that it was an array. A hasty glance, however,
would lead you to believe that it was validating an array of
parameter_types.id_string[1] and so we translated that to the new role
object validation. However, id_string doesn't include some valid role
names like _member_. This patch updates the role name schema to match
parameter_types.name, which is the same as the schema for the main role
object.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/trust/schema.py?id=62f9e57cd81dc98c5816da9fa483d385b4c1a66c#n41

Change-Id: I83aafc7a96e81a9b6b1056b39cd8c5d23676c014
Closes-bug: #1734871
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/15/523415/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add support for hybrid messaging backends

This commit separates the messaging rpc and notify transports in order
to support separate and different oslo.messaging backends

This patch:
* add rpc and notify variables
* update service role conf templates
* add example to globals.yaml
* add release note

Implements: blueprint hybrid-messaging
Change-Id: I34691c2895c8563f1f322f0850ecff98d11b5185

commit_message:
tempest: Use kwargs for create_server

As create_server() method is a wrapper around create_server() for compute
API, this patch adds support to pass kwargs parameters down to compute
API.

Change-Id: I0c970944c8f4de5c00e25f37e60206717cea4761

commit_message:
Catch socket.timeout when doing heartbeat_check

heartbeat_check in kombu.connection is not reraising exceptions as
exceptions.OperationalError, and the socket timeout during the heartbeat
check is really an issue seen in the field when a node goes down; the
heartbeat thread just tries again and again to deal with it, without
success.

Change-Id: I26dbdb18a7e64946db2cba676764ff2d428c7897
Closes-Bug: #1657444
(cherry picked from commit 8bfc3637a25a29583b1e0625c78bf159ac878259)

subject: Add regression test for rebuild with new image doubling allocations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-17 18:19:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/26945be3b3c19986bd2d2046add96d83b6e4a9f3', 'message': "WIP: Add regression test for rebuild with new image doubling allocations

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 makes a rebuild
with a new image go through the scheduler again to validate the
image against the instance.host (we rebuild to the same host that
the instance already lives on).

The problem is that change introduced a regression where the
FilterScheduler is going to think it's doing a resize to the same
host and double the allocations for the instance (and usage for the
compute node provider) in Placement, which is wrong since the
flavor is the same.

This adds a regression test to show the bug.

Change-Id: Ie0949b4e6101f0b29ec4542146d523a07a683991
Related-Bug: #1664931

commit_message:
Add regression test for rebuild with new image doubling allocations

Commit 984dd8ad6add4523d93c7ce5a666a32233e02e34 makes a rebuild
with a new image go through the scheduler again to validate the
image against the instance.host (we rebuild to the same host that
the instance already lives on).

The problem is that change introduced a regression where the
FilterScheduler is going to think it's doing a resize to the same
host and double the allocations for the instance (and usage for the
compute node provider) in Placement, which is wrong since the
flavor is the same.

This adds a regression test to show the bug.

Change-Id: Ie0949b4e6101f0b29ec4542146d523a07a683991
Related-Bug: #1664931
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/521153/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_rebuild_with_new_image(self): """Rebuilds a server with a different image which will run it through the scheduler to validate the image is still OK with the compute host that the instance is running on. Validates that additional resources are not allocated against the instance.host in Placement due to the rebuild on same host. TODO: Need a similar test with a volume-backed server; bug 1732947 """ admin_api = self.api_fixture.admin_api admin_api.microversion = '2.53' # TODO(mriedem): Consider using GET /os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_id} # so that we can check usage values without the Placement API, because # this might need to get backported to branches that don't use # Placement. def _get_provider_uuid_by_host(host): resp = admin_api.api_get( 'os-hypervisors?hypervisor_hostname_pattern=%s' % host).body return resp['hypervisors'][0]['id'] def _get_provider_usages(provider_uuid): return self.placement_api.get( '/resource_providers/%s/usages' % provider_uuid).body['usages'] def _get_allocations_by_server_uuid(server_uuid): return self.placement_api.get( '/allocations/%s' % server_uuid).body['allocations'] def assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(flavor, allocation): self.assertEqual(flavor['vcpus'], allocation['VCPU']) self.assertEqual(flavor['ram'], allocation['MEMORY_MB']) self.assertEqual(flavor['disk'], allocation['DISK_GB']) def assertFlavorsMatchAllocation(old_flavor, new_flavor, allocation): self.assertEqual(old_flavor['vcpus'] + new_flavor['vcpus'], allocation['VCPU']) self.assertEqual(old_flavor['ram'] + new_flavor['ram'], allocation['MEMORY_MB']) self.assertEqual(old_flavor['disk'] + new_flavor['disk'], allocation['DISK_GB']) nodename = self.compute.manager._get_nodename(None) rp_uuid = _get_provider_uuid_by_host(nodename) # make sure we start with no usage on the compute node rp_usages = _get_provider_usages(rp_uuid) self.assertEqual({'VCPU': 0, 'MEMORY_MB': 0, 'DISK_GB': 0}, rp_usages) server_req_body = { 'server': { # We hard-code from a fake image since we can't get images # via the compute /images proxy API with microversion > 2.35. 'imageRef': '155d900f-4e14-4e4c-a73d-069cbf4541e6', 'flavorRef': '1', # m1.tiny from DefaultFlavorsFixture, 'name': 'test_rebuild_with_new_image', # We don't care about networking for this test. This requires # microversion >= 2.37. 'networks': 'none' } } server = self.api.post_server(server_req_body) self._wait_for_state_change(self.api, server, 'ACTIVE') flavor = self.api.api_get('/flavors/1').body['flavor'] # There should be usage for the server on the compute node now. rp_usages = _get_provider_usages(rp_uuid) assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(flavor, rp_usages) allocs = _get_allocations_by_server_uuid(server['id']) self.assertIn(rp_uuid, allocs) allocs = allocs[rp_uuid]['resources'] assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(flavor, allocs) rebuild_image_ref = ( nova.tests.unit.image.fake.AUTO_DISK_CONFIG_ENABLED_IMAGE_UUID) # Now rebuild the server with that updated image. rebuild_req_body = { 'rebuild': { 'imageRef': rebuild_image_ref } } self.api.api_post('/servers/%s/action' % server['id'], rebuild_req_body) self._wait_for_server_parameter( self.api, server, {'OS-EXT-STS:task_state': None}) # The usage and allocations should not have changed. rp_usages = _get_provider_usages(rp_uuid) # FIXME(mriedem): This is a bug where the scheduler doubled up the # allocations for the instance even though we're just rebuilding # to the same host. commit_message:
Add instance action record for lock/unlock instances

We currently don't record lock/unlock instance
actions. This is useful for auditing and debugging.

This patch adds instance lock/unlock actions.

Change-Id: I09fadf79aac1a74465af48015ef97d9e9d4ac580
partial-implements: blueprint fill-the-gap-for-instance-action-records

commit_message:
Implement query param schema for sec group APIs

sec group APIs accept query param to filter the
quota.
This commit adds json schema to validate the valid
query parameters.

There is no change in API behaviour and additionalProperties
is kept True for backward compatibility.

Partially implements blueprint json-schema-validation-for-query-param

Change-Id: If55296e0efe6676bb931aad8b2b0133efbb910a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/521353/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_list_with_invalid_filter( self, url, expected_exception=exception.ValidationError): prefix = '/fake/os-security-groups' req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank(prefix + url) self.assertRaises(expected_exception, self.controller.index, req) def test_list_with_invalid_non_int_limit(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter('?limit=-9') def test_list_with_invalid_string_limit(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter('?limit=abc') def test_list_duplicate_query_with_invalid_string_limit(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter( '?limit=1&limit=abc') def test_list_with_invalid_non_int_offset(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter('?offset=-9') def test_list_with_invalid_string_offset(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter('?offset=abc') def test_list_duplicate_query_with_invalid_string_offset(self): self._test_list_with_invalid_filter( '?offset=1&offset=abc') def test_list_duplicate_query_parameters_validation(self): params = { 'limit': 1, 'offset': 1, 'all_tenants': 1 } for param, value in params.items(): req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank( '/fake/os-security-groups' + '?%s=%s&%s=%s' % (param, value, param, value)) self.controller.index(req) def test_list_with_additional_filter(self): req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank( '/fake/os-security-groups?limit=1&offset=1&additional=something') self.controller.index(req) def test_list_all_tenants_filter_as_string(self): req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank( '/fake/os-security-groups?all_tenants=abc') self.controller.index(req) def test_list_all_tenants_filter_as_positive_int(self): req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank( '/fake/os-security-groups?all_tenants=1') self.controller.index(req) def test_list_all_tenants_filter_as_negative_int(self): req = fakes.HTTPRequest.blank( '/fake/os-security-groups?all_tenants=-1') self.controller.index(req)

commit_message:
[Docs] Clarify ceph production example.

There are details that confuse people (like the usage of may), when
they are configuring a ceph environment.

This should clarify the situation.

Change-Id: Ic8b734eabcfa218c687db69290c8b3cef1def7c5

commit_message:
Extend comparator support for project list by tags

This changes allows operator to use the keystoneclient to filter
projects with tags using comparators including 'startswith',
'endswith', and 'contains'.

Change-Id: Ib85e105824afb70a8dac8b5f684daef301b03786
Partially-Implements: bp project-tags
Depends-On: I00f094a5584be40ab477cbf680a5f6d1afb4d21b
Depends-On: I0983a5b592aaffa9cef38c74c038fa60a176786c
Co-Authored-By: Omar Tleimat <otleimat@ucla.edu>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/78/495978/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def filter_by_attributes(cls, refs, hints): """Filter a list of references by filter values.""" def _attr_match(ref_attr, val_attr): """Matche attributes allowing for booleans as strings. We test explicitly for a value that defines it as 'False', which also means that the existence of the attribute with no value implies 'True' """ if type(ref_attr) is bool: return ref_attr == utils.attr_as_boolean(val_attr) else: return ref_attr == val_attr def _inexact_attr_match(filter, ref): """Apply an inexact filter to a result dict. :param filter: the filter in question :param ref: the dict to check :returns: True if there is a match """ comparator = filter['comparator'] key = filter['name'] #key is tags_any #comparator is startswith if key in ref and 'tag' not in key: #filter['value'] = Gen filter_value = filter['value'] ## todo: point the target_value to tags when the key is tags, tags_any, not_tags, not_tags_any ## maybe do an if 'tag' in key ## for loop through tags and run startswith on the target value until target_value = ref[key] if not filter['case_sensitive']: # We only support inexact filters on strings so # it's OK to use lower() filter_value = filter_value.lower() target_value = target_value.lower() if comparator == 'contains': return (filter_value in target_value) elif comparator == 'startswith': return target_value.startswith(filter_value) elif comparator == 'endswith': return target_value.endswith(filter_value) else: # We silently ignore unsupported filters return True # This is for when you pass in tags and comparators like contains, startswith, endswith. Tags cannot # use the current comparator logic in _inexact_attr_match off the box because of the key in ref, and # the logic is slightly different because it is a list not a string. if 'tag' in key: filter_value = filter['value'] target_value = ref['tags'] if comparator == 'startswith' or comparator == 'endswith': if key == 'tags': if target_value == []: return False elif all(getattr(tag, comparator)(filter_value) for tag in target_value): return True else: return False elif key == 'tags_any': return any(getattr(tag, comparator)(filter_value) for tag in target_value) elif key == 'not_tags': if target_value == []: return True elif all(getattr(tag, comparator)(filter_value) for tag in target_value): return False else: return True elif key == 'not_tags_any': return not any(getattr(tag, comparator)(filter_value) for tag in target_value) elif comparator == 'contains': if key == 'tags': if target_value == []: return False elif all((filter_value in tag) for tag in target_value): return True else: return False elif key == 'tags_any': return any((filter_value in tag) for tag in target_value) elif key == 'not_tags': if target_value == []: return True elif all((filter_value in tag) for tag in target_value): return False else: return True elif key == 'not_tags_any': return not any((filter_value in tag) for tag in target_value) else: return True return False for filter in hints.filters: if filter['comparator'] == 'equals': attr = filter['name'] value = filter['value'] refs = [r for r in refs if _attr_match( utils.flatten_dict(r).get(attr), value)] else: # It might be an inexact filter refs = [r for r in refs if _inexact_attr_match( filter, r)] return refs 'parent_id', 'is_domain', 'tags', 'tags_any', 'not_tags', 'not_tags_any')

commit_message:
Revert "Add package install assertions to SUSE base image"

This reverts commit 163341e624ec4d2dba39d6ac140111aa6a809baa.

The systemd from Tumbleweed is not fully functional inside the container

container1:/home/vagrant # systemctl status
Failed to connect to bus: No such file or directory

and because of that services are not working

wicked: Unable to connect to wicked dbus service", "wicked: Cannot get
dbus system bus handle (Failed to connect to socket
/run/dbus/system_bus_socket: No such file or directory)

As such, lets revert this commit until this is properly tested.

Change-Id: I2ccc941f8e961ced3d77b5e86e20d4ce29e778ee

Enable in-tree .htaccess for heat

Allow deep redirects of old pages like those from the template guide
that are linked from all over the web.

commit_message:
Fix deep_links macro in .htaccess

Because the trailing / is optional, the deep_links macro could match
multiple projects if one of their names is a prefix of the other(s)
(e.g. heat and heat-translator). It also means that completely bogus
paths will redirect to bogus locations - e.g. currently
https://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova-foo redirects to
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/-foo

Avoid this by adding a negative-lookahead assertion, to ensure that the
path passed in by the caller of the macro is not followed by any non-/
character.

Change-Id: I9dcf5dccfa36a3b1895f4422deafcdb73b150cbd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/14/518614/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Do *not* redirect if only a prefix matches {{ deep_links('/developer/' + project.name + '-bogus', '', 200) }}

commit_message:
[RFC] [DNM] (optionally) be gauche

For testing and development we might want to skip some lifecycle
action when not useful.

Change-Id: Ib008e36426de65fd90c79166349b6d4a4f5abf3d

commit_message:
Describe common quickstart and extras defaults

Add non_root_user, undercloud_key, undercloud_user, local_working_dir,
working_dir, overcloud_user and overcloud_key default values to the common
role defaults. These are shared for *multiple* quickstart and extras use cases,
like undercloud/overcloud/external deployments, virtual, barematal or OVB.

An implicit defaults for these bring confusion for quickstart users, and
complicate deployed servers customizations, like overcloud user and key and
working dir to contain the latter.

Closes-bug: #1663420
Closes-bug: #1688254
Related-bug: #1734298

Change-Id: I33ee791aee0799fdc430fdbea52db75f8ef8ef33
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/71/522771/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: non_root_user: stack working_dir: "/home/{{ non_root_user }}" local_working_dir: "{{ lookup('env', 'HOME') }}/.quickstart" undercloud_user: "{{ non_root_user }}" undercloud_key: "{{ local_working_dir }}/id_rsa_undercloud" overcloud_key: "{{ local_working_dir }}/id_rsa_overcloud" overcloud_user: heat-admin

subject: Wrong handling of is_system flag at workbooks causes DB error with MySQL 5.7
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-24 13:55:59.000000000', 'files': ['mistral/services/workbooks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/f254c3925737aa8bb53d4072681bc6f7ab7893ff', 'message': "Wrong handling of is_system flag at workbooks causes DB error with MySQL 5.7

If we leave is_system workbook attribute as undefined (Null) that causes
database insert error in MySQL 5.7, due to database constraints.
So let's use constant False as is_system attribute in workbook create.
It is OK, because there is no system workbook support in mistral yet.

Change-Id: Idabf9d04d105c2386b9b110f1bbab3e69502b8e0
Closes-Bug: #1733501
"}]
commit_message:
Wrong handling of is_system flag at workbooks causes DB error with MySQL 5.7

If we leave is_system workbook attribute as undefined (Null) that causes
database insert error in MySQL 5.7, due to database constraints.
So let's use constant False as is_system attribute in workbook create.
It is OK, because there is no system workbook support in mistral yet.

Change-Id: Idabf9d04d105c2386b9b110f1bbab3e69502b8e0
Closes-Bug: #1733501
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/23/522823/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'tags': wf_spec.get_tags(), 'is_system': False 'scope': scope, 'is_system': False

commit_message:
Skip tempest jobs for doc/* only changes

Neutron repo contains doc/ directory to store install and other guides.
We should not execute tempest jobs if a patch touches those files only.

Change-Id: If5003bb573e959a2324eab62cc08822c6e28e5f4

commit_message:
Use os_workers when applicable

This uses os_workers as default for every workers config setting of the
various services.

Change-Id: I828f7fd8000d8e386b4d794ba8bf308599aa5491

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Global Role Assignments ======================= `bp global-roles <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/global-roles>`_ This document describes the necessary changes in order to implement global role assignments. Problem Description =================== Today, role assignments are built by giving an actor a role on a target. An actor can be a user or a group. A target is limited to a project or a domain. This works great for controlling access to things that map into a project or domain (i.e. instance ownership fits naturally within projects). This starts to get confusing with operations that don't fit within that constraint. Live migrating an instance from one host to another is a good example of this. A global role assignment would be an assignment with the target being `global` instead of a project or a domain. Proposed Change =============== The following is an example request for a globally scoped token:: { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "password" ], "password": { "user": { "id": "8bbca32b850a4c22b64a1b7bc2c6bd13", "password": "my-password" } } }, "scope": "global" } } An example response would be:: { [2/21] "token": { "audit_ids": [ "doIh18J8RyW3jXF50FV26g" ], "catalog": [ ... ], "expires_at": "2017-05-15T21:58:29.000000Z", "is_domain": false, "issued_at": "2017-05-15T20:58:29.000000Z", "methods": [ "password" ], "global": true, "roles": [ { "id": "c2145c84a802413fbac71479250c9378", "name": "observer" }, { "id": "fc2ec22e227941f8afd94a1587ac57d3", "name": "admin" } ], "user": { "domain": { "id": "default", "name": "Default" }, "id": "8bbca32b850a4c22b64a1b7bc2c6bd13", "name": "bob", "password_expires_at": null } } } Alternatives ------------ An alternative to this approach would be to leverage the `admin_project` in order to achieve global scoping. The `admin_project` is a special project that allows for elevated privileges if role assignment are given to that project. Let's consider the following example. Let's there is an `observer` role that allows users to do non-destructive operations within a specific scope. If Bob has the `observer` role on project `foo`, he should be able to view things within that tenancy. If Alice has the `observer` role on the `admin_project`, she should be able to view things across the deployment, like services and endpoints. In this model, global scope is determined by a specific project and the role assignments that project has. Every user that requires a global role (i.e. admin, observer, support, etc) in a deployment will be required to have a role assignment on the `admin_project`. Security Impact --------------- This type of scoping will allow OpenStack services to separate global operations from project or domain scoped operations. The result will be an improved security model across OpenStack. Notifications Impact -------------------- Global scoping will be subject to the same notification as project or domain scope requests. Other End User Impact --------------------- This is highly dependent on how operators have configured their policy across OpenStack. Ideally, this will give operators more tools to provide better security in their deployments. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers will now have the ability to control global operations by leverage global role assignments. The ability will be available by default but a migration won't be supplied to migrate existing admin-ness workarounds. Developer Impact ---------------- This work will most-likely require some changes to testing both inside and outside of keystone, in order to fix admin-ness issues. Mitigating this will be a required work item of the implementation. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Migrate the assignment table to support global targets * Implement global role assignment * Implement scoping a token to a global context * Migrate tempest testing to leverage global roles * Implement global context in `oslo.policy` Follow on work items should be done to ensure global role assignments are honored within policies across OpenStack: * Ensure default policies adhere to global scope * Ensure scope checks across projects enforce global scope Dependencies ============ None. Documentation Impact ==================== We will need to provide a more consistent authentication document that clearly explains scope at the project, domain, and global levels. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Allow EOL branches to use the test-matrix.py script

When running devstack on EOL tags the feature matrix rejects the
branch reference as unsupported even though it can actually support it.
This patch adds an additional check to the normalize function to allow
branches/references in the format "branch-eol" to be normalized and
processed correctly.

Change-Id: Ie605969bb81c97072e909b50f9e9e33c0164f900

commit_message:
config: Always add step conditional first for upgrade_tasks

This is required to ensure conditionals using variables set by prior
steps are not evaluated prior to these steps running.

Closes-bug: #1732888
Change-Id: I9f6d60f22ef4c057a0d5f47ac2bd4f08520faeec
(cherry picked from commit 78a5bc0554f7571bce9794618e3c653c109a90b1)

commit_message:
Select first node as bootstrap node not using name

This fixes a regression which reintroduced bug #1640449 because
we hard-code the node index/name instead of sorting the map of servers

Change-Id: Iaffc66a41edf176dde3b5adf603a9cff6db7aa24
Closes-Bug: #1724888

commit_message:
Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: I30123183ad3d4a0078fbb92941b2b8e8aadd6d1c
Closes-Bug: 1734620
(cherry picked from commit f5a7315c2fa7aeeb652f4825c10e1d491bd1b319)

commit_message:
Add new options in volume driver base class

This commit is to add two options in the volume driver base class.

We add 'api_server_ip' and 'api_server_port' for setting the IP
address and the port of the volume backend.

Change-Id: Idac6f57512a45262ac76c78c88c3b474409ab786
Implements: blueprint add-new-option-in-volume-driver-base-class

commit_message:
Start sequence at 1 for deploy steps playbook

We should start the sequence at 1 instead of 0, since all our puppet
manifests assume the first step is 1. Trying to run our puppet manifests
with a hieradata value of step=0 actually results in an error because no
classes are included.

Change-Id: I93dc8b4cefbd729ba7afa3a4d81b4ac95344cac2
Closes-Bug: #1717292
(cherry picked from commit 320f80dbae3bb7b8b57239a5da99c0020a7f8a12)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/03/522803/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Start sequence at 1 for the downloaded deploy steps playbook instead of 0. The first step should be 1 since that is what the puppet manifests expect.

commit_message:
run_tests_common.sh: Add more openSUSE packages

We need to explicitly pull the python-xml and ca-certificates-mozilla
packages which may not exist on really small openSUSE images. These
packages are needed for a functional SSL setup and also for being
able to run pip.

Change-Id: Ib518cff03dbfdbfa7c31729521c265e7a3e7e9cf
(cherry picked from commit c28727540d3c9ed0641d5052c67b4500aac330e9)

commit_message:
Fixes the deletion on click action assignment

Changes the selector used to assign the delete on
click action to the correct button in the modal
confirmation dialog.

In addition, the code that hides the "working"
modal to the success handler of said delete action;
the modal should now appear while elements are
actually being deleted and disappearing after
the operation finishes.

Closes-Bug: 1733324
Change-Id: Ia14c263ed49c6f9705dbe12e8108a2c8c858aa31

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 14.2.13

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 15.1.13

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

commit_message:
Set host name explicitly for telemetry

Without this there could be a mismatch with other services like
nova and neutron and ceilometer wont find nova instances.

Closes-bug: #1721054

Depends-On: I421a61dc31bd10fec0a10bf7e867001cf4dd3f02

Change-Id: I92f6d351931f1ea598d6a382704e8f986129be42

commit_message:
Adds extra args for kube_scheduler deploy

This adds extra args for the kube-scheduler to expose metrics on
port 10251 on all interfaces. This allows for Prometheus to gather
metrics for the scheduler

Change-Id: I26d473f511f6541a14a9387be1ce56841572bfff

Test runner polls neutron-server for agents for default value of
wait_until_true() which is 60 seconds. It has been proven to be

commit_message:
fullstack: Wait at least 3 minute for agents to report

Test runner polls neutron-server for agents for default value of
wait_until_true() which is 60 seconds. It has been proven to be
insufficient time on busy environments. This patch bumps the timeout to
3 minutes and also highers polling interval from 1 seconds to 10
seconds, to offload neutron-server.

Change-Id: I108176ee5668c2bc456dda1810aa509212e7cb38
Closes-bug: #1734357
